sections.title: DNA Sequencing (Reading)
keyPoints: Sequencing by synthesis (SBS) is the dominant short-read approach, used by Illumina, MGI/BGI, and Element Biosciences
Illumina SBS uses reversible fluorescent terminators on flow cell clusters, reading ~150-300 bp per read with very high accuracy
MGI/BGI uses DNA nanoballs (DNB) on patterned arrays with combinatorial probe-anchor synthesis (cPAS)
Single-molecule long-read sequencing (PacBio SMRT, Oxford Nanopore) can read 10 kb to over 1 Mb fragments
PacBio uses zero-mode waveguides (ZMWs) to observe a single polymerase incorporating fluorescently labeled nucleotides in real time
Oxford Nanopore measures ionic current disruptions as single-stranded DNA passes through a protein pore, enabling real-time portable sequencing
Spatial omics and in situ sequencing methods read RNA or DNA directly in tissue sections, preserving spatial context
Protein sequencing is advancing through single-molecule approaches including fluorosequencing and nanopore-based methods

vocabulary.definition: A sequencing method where nucleotides are added one at a time to a growing complementary strand, and each incorporation event is detected optically or electronically. The basis for Illumina, MGI, and Element platforms.
A glass or silicon surface coated with short oligonucleotide adapters to which DNA library fragments bind and are clonally amplified into clusters for sequencing.
A modified nucleotide with a fluorescent label and a 3'-blocking group that stops polymerase extension after each incorporation, allowing single-base detection before chemical removal of the block.

A nanophotonic structure (tiny hole in a metal film ~70 nm diameter) that confines light to observe a single DNA polymerase molecule incorporating fluorescent nucleotides in real time (PacBio SMRT sequencing).

A method where a single strand of DNA or RNA is threaded through a protein pore embedded in a membrane; characteristic disruptions in ionic current identify each base. Used by Oxford Nanopore Technologies (ONT).
A compact ball of concatenated copies of a circular DNA template, generated by rolling circle amplification. Used by MGI/BGI sequencers to achieve high-density patterned arrays.
Methods that measure gene expression while preserving the physical location of transcripts within a tissue section, combining sequencing data with spatial coordinates.
The number of contiguous bases determined from a single sequencing read. Short-read platforms produce 75-300 bp; long-read platforms can exceed 10 kb to over 1 Mb.

sections.details:
The Sequencing Revolution

DNA sequencing, the ability to read the genetic code, has undergone a dramatic transformation since the Sanger method of the 1970s. Modern next-generation sequencing (NGS) platforms achieve massively parallel reads at a fraction of the original cost, enabling whole-genome sequencing for under $200. George Church's lecture emphasized that reading DNA is the foundational capability upon which writing and editing depend.

Short-Read Sequencing by Synthesis

Illumina dominates the short-read market. Library DNA fragments are adapter-ligated, bound to a flow cell surface, and clonally amplified into clusters via bridge amplification. During each sequencing cycle, all four fluorescently labeled reversible terminators compete for incorporation by the polymerase. After imaging, the fluorophore and 3'-blocking group are chemically cleaved, and the next cycle begins. This produces reads of 150-300 bp with error rates below 0.1%.

MGI/BGI uses a different amplification strategy: rolling circle amplification generates DNA nanoballs (DNBs) that are loaded onto patterned arrays. Sequencing uses combinatorial probe-anchor synthesis (cPAS) rather than single-nucleotide addition. Element Biosciences represents a newer entrant using avidity sequencing, which employs multivalent nucleotide-polymer conjugates to improve signal-to-noise.

Long-Read Single-Molecule Sequencing

PacBio SMRT sequencing places a single polymerase at the bottom of each zero-mode waveguide (ZMW). As the polymerase incorporates phospholinked fluorescent nucleotides, the fluorophore is cleaved during incorporation, generating a real-time movie of base additions. HiFi mode uses circular consensus sequencing (CCS) to achieve >99.9% accuracy over ~15-20 kb reads.

Oxford Nanopore threads native DNA or RNA through an engineered protein pore (e.g., R10.4.1) embedded in an electrically resistant membrane. Each base (or base modification) causes a characteristic current disruption. This enables ultra-long reads (>1 Mb demonstrated), direct detection of methylation and other modifications without bisulfite conversion, and portable field sequencing with devices as small as the MinION.

Spatial Omics & Protein Sequencing

Spatial transcriptomics methods (Visium, MERFISH, Slide-seq) combine sequencing or hybridization readouts with preserved tissue architecture, revealing which genes are active in which cell types in situ. Protein sequencing is also advancing: single-molecule fluorosequencing labels N-terminal amino acids with fluorophores and tracks sequential Edman degradation cycles, while nanopore-based approaches are being developed to read peptide sequences directly.

quizQuestions.question: In Illumina sequencing by synthesis, what prevents the polymerase from incorporating more than one nucleotide per cycle?
options: The DNA template is single-stranded and cannot hold more than one nucleotide
A reversible 3'-blocking group on each nucleotide stops extension after one incorporation
The laser photobleaches the fluorophore, halting the polymerase
Bridge amplification resets the strand after each base
quizQuestions.explanation: Each nucleotide carries a reversible terminator: a 3'-blocking group that prevents further extension until it is chemically cleaved, ensuring exactly one base is incorporated and detected per cycle.

quizQuestions.question: What structure does PacBio SMRT sequencing use to observe a single DNA polymerase molecule?
options: A protein nanopore in a lipid membrane
A zero-mode waveguide (ZMW) nanophotonic well
A quantum dot attached to the polymerase
A flow cell with clonal clusters
quizQuestions.explanation: ZMWs are nanoscale holes (~70 nm) in a metal film. The observation volume is so small that only the fluorescent nucleotide being incorporated by the polymerase at the bottom of the well is detected, while freely diffusing nucleotides above contribute negligible background.

quizQuestions.question: What is a key advantage of Oxford Nanopore sequencing over short-read platforms?
options: It has lower per-base error rates than Illumina
It requires clonal amplification of DNA templates
It can produce ultra-long reads (>100 kb) and directly detect base modifications
It uses reversible terminators for high accuracy
quizQuestions.explanation: Nanopore sequencing reads native DNA strands directly without amplification, enabling ultra-long reads and detection of base modifications (5mC, 6mA) in real time. While per-read accuracy has improved greatly, its primary advantages are read length and direct modification detection.

quizQuestions.question: How does MGI/BGI generate its sequencing templates?
options: Bridge amplification on a flow cell surface
Rolling circle amplification to create DNA nanoballs (DNBs)
Emulsion PCR on ion sphere particles
Linear amplification with T7 RNA polymerase
quizQuestions.explanation: MGI/BGI circularizes library fragments and performs rolling circle amplification to generate compact DNA nanoballs (DNBs), which are then loaded onto patterned nanoarrays for sequencing by combinatorial probe-anchor synthesis (cPAS).

sections.title: DNA Synthesis (Writing)
keyPoints: Chemical DNA synthesis uses phosphoramidite chemistry: a cycle of deprotection, coupling, capping, and oxidation repeated for each base
Chemical synthesis has an error rate of ~1 in 100 (1:10^2), while biological replication achieves ~1 in 1,000,000 (1:10^6) due to proofreading
Column-based synthesis produces one oligo at a time; chip-based synthesis (Twist, Agilent) produces ~1 million oligos per chip at ~1000x lower cost per oligo
Gene synthesis assembles short oligos (150-300 nt) into full genes using overlap assembly methods like Gibson Assembly
Gibson Assembly joins overlapping DNA fragments in a single isothermal reaction using three enzymes: exonuclease, polymerase, and ligase
Error correction using mismatch-binding proteins (like MutS) or enzymatic approaches can improve synthetic DNA fidelity
Enzymatic DNA synthesis using terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is an emerging alternative that works in aqueous conditions without toxic chemicals
DNA data storage encodes digital information in synthetic DNA sequences, achieving extremely high information density (~10^18 bytes per gram)

vocabulary.definition: The standard method for chemical DNA synthesis. Each nucleotide is added as a phosphoramidite monomer (with protecting groups on the base and phosphate) in a four-step cycle: deprotection of the 5'-DMT group, coupling of the next phosphoramidite, capping of unreacted sites, and oxidation of the phosphite to phosphate.

The percentage of chains that successfully add the next nucleotide in each synthesis cycle. Typical values are 98-99.5%. Over a 200-mer, even 99% efficiency yields only ~13% full-length product (0.99^200).

An isothermal (50 degrees C) in vitro method for joining multiple overlapping DNA fragments in a single reaction. Uses T5 exonuclease (creates 3' overhangs), Phusion polymerase (fills gaps), and Taq ligase (seals nicks).

A complex mixture of thousands to millions of distinct oligonucleotides synthesized simultaneously on a chip surface (e.g., Twist oligo pools). Used for gene synthesis, CRISPR libraries, and probe sets.

A method where the growing oligonucleotide chain is attached to an insoluble solid support (controlled pore glass or polystyrene beads), allowing reagents and byproducts to be washed away between steps.

A template-independent DNA polymerase that adds nucleotides to the 3' end of single-stranded DNA. Being developed as the basis for enzymatic DNA synthesis, which avoids the harsh organic solvents of phosphoramidite chemistry.

A post-synthesis quality improvement step using the mismatch-binding protein MutS (or similar enzymes) to selectively remove or deplete oligos containing synthesis errors (mismatches, insertions, deletions).

A bulky, acid-labile protecting group on the 5'-hydroxyl of each phosphoramidite monomer. Its removal (deprotection) at the start of each synthesis cycle exposes the hydroxyl for coupling to the next nucleotide.

sections.details:
From Nucleotide to Gene: The Art of DNA Writing

DNA synthesis, or gene writing, is the ability to construct arbitrary DNA sequences from scratch. Joseph Jacobson's lecture framed cells as programmable factories whose instruction sets we can now write from first principles. Emily Leproust (Twist Bioscience) traced the history from Michelson and Todd's first dinucleotide synthesis in 1955 through Caruthers' phosphoramidite method in 1981 to today's silicon chip-based massively parallel synthesis.

Phosphoramidite Chemistry: The Workhorse

Nearly all commercial DNA synthesis uses phosphoramidite chemistry on a solid support. The synthesis cycle has four steps:

1. Deprotection: The 5'-DMT (dimethoxytrityl) protecting group is removed with acid (trichloroacetic acid, TCA), exposing the 5'-hydroxyl for the next coupling. In chip-based photodeprotection variants, light removes a photolabile group instead of acid.

2. Coupling: The next phosphoramidite monomer is activated with tetrazole and reacts with the free 5'-hydroxyl. Coupling efficiency is typically 98-99.5%, but even small failures compound over long oligos. For a 200-mer at 99% efficiency, only about 13% of chains are full-length (0.99200 = 0.13).

3. Capping: Unreacted 5'-hydroxyls are acetylated to prevent them from participating in subsequent cycles, which would produce deletion products.

4. Oxidation: The newly formed phosphite triester is oxidized to a stable phosphate triester with iodine.

Column vs. Chip-Based Synthesis

Traditional column synthesis produces one oligo sequence per column, suitable for high-quantity single sequences. Chip-based synthesis (Twist Bioscience, Agilent, CustomArray) uses silicon wafers or microarrays to synthesize approximately 1 million distinct oligos per chip, reducing cost by roughly 1000-fold per oligo. Twist uses a proprietary silicon platform where each well contains a miniaturized synthesis column.

From Oligos to Genes: Assembly Methods

Since chemical synthesis is limited to roughly 150-300 nucleotides per oligo, longer constructs require assembly. Gibson Assembly is the most widely used method: overlapping fragments (20-40 bp overlaps) are combined in a single isothermal reaction at 50 degrees C with three enzymes. The T5 exonuclease chews back 5' ends to expose complementary 3' overhangs, which anneal. Phusion DNA polymerase fills gaps, and Taq DNA ligase seals nicks. This can join 5-10+ fragments in one reaction.

Error Rates and Error Correction

A critical challenge in DNA synthesis is the error rate gap: chemical synthesis introduces roughly 1 error per 100-200 bases (1:102), while biological DNA replication achieves 1 error per 1,000,000 bases (1:106) thanks to polymerase proofreading and mismatch repair. To bridge this gap, post-synthesis error correction uses mismatch-binding proteins like MutS, which selectively binds to heteroduplex DNA at mismatch sites. Treated pools are enriched for correct sequences.

Emerging: Enzymatic Synthesis and DNA Data Storage

Enzymatic DNA synthesis using TdT (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase) adds nucleotides in aqueous solution without organic solvents, potentially enabling longer oligos, cheaper reagents, and greener chemistry. Companies like DNA Script are commercializing this approach.

DNA data storage encodes binary information into DNA base sequences. Because DNA is extraordinarily dense (~1018 bytes per gram), stable for thousands of years in the right conditions, and requires no power to maintain, it represents a compelling archival storage medium. Church's lab demonstrated early DNA data storage in 2012 by encoding an entire book into DNA.

quizQuestions.question: What is the approximate error rate difference between chemical DNA synthesis and biological DNA replication?
options: Chemical is ~1:10^2, biological is ~1:10^6 (10,000-fold difference)
Chemical is ~1:10^4, biological is ~1:10^6 (100-fold difference)
Chemical is ~1:10^6, biological is ~1:10^9 (1000-fold difference)
They have approximately the same error rate
quizQuestions.explanation: Chemical DNA synthesis has an error rate of roughly 1 in 100 bases (1:10^2), while biological replication with proofreading achieves about 1 in 1,000,000 (1:10^6). This ~10,000-fold gap is why error correction is so important in synthetic biology.

quizQuestions.question: What three enzymes are used in Gibson Assembly?
options: Restriction endonuclease, DNA polymerase, and DNA ligase
T5 exonuclease, Phusion DNA polymerase, and Taq DNA ligase
T7 RNA polymerase, reverse transcriptase, and RNase H
Cas9 nuclease, terminal transferase, and topoisomerase
quizQuestions.explanation: Gibson Assembly uses T5 exonuclease (to create single-stranded 3' overhangs), Phusion DNA polymerase (to fill gaps), and Taq DNA ligase (to seal nicks). The reaction runs isothermally at 50 degrees C.

quizQuestions.question: Why does chip-based DNA synthesis (e.g., Twist) reduce cost compared to column-based synthesis?
options: It uses cheaper phosphoramidite reagents with lower purity
It synthesizes ~1 million different oligos per chip in parallel, sharing the fixed costs
It eliminates the need for deprotection and capping steps
It replaces chemical synthesis entirely with enzymatic synthesis
quizQuestions.explanation: Chip-based synthesis uses silicon wafers or microarrays to synthesize approximately 1 million distinct oligos simultaneously on a single chip, spreading the cost of reagents and equipment across many sequences. This achieves roughly 1000x lower cost per oligo compared to column synthesis.

quizQuestions.question: What role does the MutS protein play in synthetic DNA error correction?
options: It synthesizes new DNA to replace erroneous segments
It adds methyl groups to mark correct sequences
It binds selectively to mismatched base pairs in heteroduplex DNA, enabling removal of error-containing sequences
It amplifies only error-free oligos using rolling circle amplification
quizQuestions.explanation: MutS is a mismatch-binding protein from the bacterial DNA repair pathway. When synthetic oligos are re-annealed to form heteroduplexes, MutS binds to positions where mismatches occur (indicating synthesis errors). MutS-bound sequences can then be removed or depleted, enriching the pool for error-free sequences.

sections.title: Gene Editing (CRISPR & Beyond)
keyPoints: CRISPR-Cas9 acts as a programmable RNA-guided nuclease: a guide RNA (gRNA) directs Cas9 to a complementary 20-nt target adjacent to a PAM sequence
CRISPR is fundamentally an RNP (ribonucleoprotein) scaffold: the Cas protein plus guide RNA form a programmable complex that can be fused to diverse effectors
Beyond cutting: catalytically dead Cas9 (dCas9) enables transcriptional activation (CRISPRa), repression (CRISPRi), base editing, and epigenetic modification
The PASTE system (Programmable Addition via Site-specific Targeting Elements) combines CRISPR with integrases to insert large DNA payloads (up to ~36 kb) at specific genomic sites
MAGE (Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering) introduces many targeted mutations simultaneously across a genome using pools of synthetic oligos and recombineering
Genomically Recoded Organisms (GROs) have had one or more codons globally reassigned, freeing codons for non-standard amino acids or creating genetic firewalls
Base editors (CBE, ABE) convert one base pair to another without double-strand breaks, achieving precise point mutations with fewer indels
Prime editing uses a Cas9 nickase fused to reverse transcriptase, guided by a pegRNA that encodes both the target and the desired edit

vocabulary.definition: A genome editing system derived from bacterial adaptive immunity. The Cas9 nuclease is guided to a specific genomic locus by a ~20-nt guide RNA complementary to the target. Cas9 creates a double-strand break, which the cell repairs by NHEJ (often causing indels) or HDR (enabling precise edits with a donor template).
A short DNA sequence (e.g., 5'-NGG-3' for SpCas9) immediately downstream of the target site that is required for Cas9 binding and cleavage. The PAM is in the target DNA, not in the guide RNA.

vocabulary.term: PASTE (Programmable Addition via Site-specific Targeting Elements)
vocabulary.definition: A CRISPR-based insertion system that combines a Cas9 nickase, a reverse transcriptase, and a serine integrase to insert large DNA cargo (up to ~36 kb) at specific genomic locations without double-strand breaks.

A technique that introduces many targeted mutations across a genome simultaneously by electroporating pools of synthetic oligonucleotides into dividing cells, exploiting the recombineering machinery. Enables rapid combinatorial genome diversification.

An organism in which one or more codons have been systematically replaced throughout the entire genome, freeing those codons for reassignment to non-standard amino acids or creating genetic isolation from natural organisms.

A fusion protein combining a catalytically impaired Cas9 (nickase) with a deaminase enzyme. Cytosine base editors (CBE) convert C-G to T-A; adenine base editors (ABE) convert A-T to G-C. Achieves precise point mutations without double-strand breaks.

A versatile editing approach using a Cas9 nickase fused to a reverse transcriptase, guided by a prime editing guide RNA (pegRNA). The pegRNA specifies both the target site and the desired edit, enabling all 12 point mutation types plus small insertions and deletions without double-strand breaks or donor DNA.

A complex of protein and RNA. In the CRISPR context, the Cas9 protein plus guide RNA form an RNP complex that serves as a programmable scaffold, emphasizing that CRISPR's power comes from RNA-directed protein function.

sections.details:
CRISPR: The Programmable Molecular Scissors

The CRISPR-Cas9 system has revolutionized genome editing since its adaptation for eukaryotic cells in 2012-2013. At its core, CRISPR is an RNA-guided nuclease: the Cas9 protein is directed to a specific 20-nucleotide target sequence by a guide RNA (gRNA). The only requirement is that the target be adjacent to a PAM sequence (5'-NGG-3' for the commonly used Streptococcus pyogenes Cas9). Upon binding, Cas9 creates a double-strand break (DSB), which the cell repairs by either non-homologous end joining (NHEJ, often introducing insertions or deletions) or homology-directed repair (HDR, enabling precise edits when a donor template is provided).

CRISPR as an RNP Scaffold

Church's lecture emphasized a powerful conceptual framework: CRISPR is fundamentally a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) scaffold. The guide RNA provides programmable targeting while the protein component provides enzymatic function. By modifying or replacing the enzymatic domain, researchers have created an entire toolkit: CRISPRa (activation, using dCas9 fused to transcriptional activators like VP64 or p65), CRISPRi (interference/repression, using dCas9 with KRAB repressor), base editors, prime editors, epigenetic modifiers, and PASTE for large insertions.

Base Editing and Prime Editing

Base editors avoid double-strand breaks entirely. Cytosine base editors (CBE) use a cytidine deaminase fused to Cas9 nickase to convert C-G to T-A base pairs. Adenine base editors (ABE) use an evolved deoxyadenosine deaminase to convert A-T to G-C. These are especially useful for correcting point mutations that cause genetic diseases.

Prime editing is even more versatile. A Cas9 nickase is fused to a reverse transcriptase and guided by a prime editing guide RNA (pegRNA) that contains both the target-binding spacer and a template encoding the desired edit. The nickase cuts one strand, the reverse transcriptase writes the new sequence from the pegRNA template, and cellular repair incorporates the edit. Prime editing can install all 12 types of point mutations, as well as small insertions and deletions.

PASTE: Large DNA Insertions

The PASTE system (Programmable Addition via Site-specific Targeting Elements) addresses a major limitation of CRISPR: inserting large DNA sequences. PASTE combines a Cas9 nickase-reverse transcriptase fusion with a serine integrase (such as Bxb1). The prime editing component first writes an integrase attachment site (attB) into the genome, and then the serine integrase catalyzes recombination between this attB site and an attP site on the donor DNA cargo. This enables insertion of payloads up to approximately 36 kb without double-strand breaks.

MAGE and Genomically Recoded Organisms

MAGE (Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering), developed in the Church lab, takes a different approach to genome engineering. Rather than editing one site at a time, MAGE introduces many targeted changes simultaneously by electroporating pools of synthetic oligonucleotides into dividing E. coli cells. The oligos are incorporated during DNA replication via lambda Red recombineering. Through iterative cycles, MAGE can generate combinatorial genetic diversity across an entire genome.

MAGE was used to create Genomically Recoded Organisms (GROs), in which all 321 instances of the UAG amber stop codon in E. coli were replaced with UAA. This freed the UAG codon for reassignment to non-standard amino acids, enabling proteins with novel chemical functionalities. GROs also serve as genetic firewalls because their altered genetic code makes them unable to exchange functional genes with wild-type organisms.

quizQuestions.question: What does it mean that CRISPR functions as an 'RNP scaffold'?
options: The RNA component provides structural support for the cell's ribosome
The guide RNA provides programmable targeting while the protein provides enzymatic function, and different effectors can be swapped onto this platform
The ribonucleoprotein can only cut DNA and has no other applications
The scaffold refers to the 3D structure of the DNA double helix
quizQuestions.explanation: Viewing CRISPR as an RNP scaffold means the guide RNA provides programmable DNA targeting (just change the 20-nt spacer sequence) while the protein component provides function. By fusing different enzymatic domains to Cas9, researchers have built an entire toolkit: nucleases, base editors, transcriptional regulators, epigenetic modifiers, and integrases.

quizQuestions.question: How does the PASTE system enable large DNA insertions?
options: It uses homology-directed repair with very long homology arms
It creates large deletions and replaces them with donor DNA via NHEJ
It first writes an integrase attachment site via prime editing, then uses a serine integrase to insert the cargo at that site
It uses multiple Cas9 cuts to create a gap that accepts large inserts
quizQuestions.explanation: PASTE is a two-step system: first, a prime editing component writes an attB integrase recognition site into the genome. Then, a serine integrase (like Bxb1) catalyzes recombination between the attB site and an attP site on the donor cargo DNA, enabling precise insertion of payloads up to ~36 kb.

quizQuestions.question: What was achieved in creating the first Genomically Recoded Organism (GRO)?
options: All instances of the AUG start codon were replaced with a synthetic codon
All 321 UAG stop codons in E. coli were replaced with UAA, freeing UAG for non-standard amino acid assignment
The organism's entire genome was synthesized from scratch using phosphoramidite chemistry
CRISPR was used to delete all non-essential genes from the genome
quizQuestions.explanation: The Church lab systematically replaced all 321 UAG amber stop codons in E. coli with the synonymous UAA ochre stop codon, then deleted the UAG-recognizing release factor. This freed UAG for reassignment to non-standard amino acids, expanding the genetic code.

quizQuestions.question: How does MAGE differ from standard CRISPR editing?
options: MAGE uses RNA interference instead of nuclease activity
MAGE only works in human cells, while CRISPR works in bacteria
MAGE introduces many targeted mutations simultaneously across a genome using pools of synthetic oligos and recombineering
MAGE requires no synthetic DNA components
quizQuestions.explanation: MAGE (Multiplex Automated Genome Engineering) electroporates pools of synthetic oligonucleotides into dividing cells, where they are incorporated during DNA replication via recombineering. This enables simultaneous modification of many genomic sites in a single cycle, generating combinatorial diversity far faster than sequential single-site editing.

sections.title: Genetic Codes & Expanded Alphabets
keyPoints: The standard genetic code uses 64 codons (4^3 triplets) to encode 20 amino acids plus stop signals, with extensive redundancy (degeneracy)
AEGIS (Artificially Expanded Genetic Information System) adds synthetic base pairs beyond A-T and G-C, such as Z-P and S-B, expanding the genetic alphabet
Non-standard amino acids (nsAAs) can be incorporated into proteins by reassigning codons (e.g., freed stop codons) to new aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase/tRNA pairs
Codon optimization adjusts synonymous codon usage to match the host organism's preferred codons, improving expression levels
The wobble position (3rd base of a codon) often tolerates substitutions without changing the amino acid, which is the basis for codon degeneracy
Mirror biology (mirror-image life) would use D-amino acids and L-sugars, raising biosafety concerns because natural immune systems and enzymes would not recognize mirror biomolecules
Expanded genetic codes could create organisms with novel capabilities: proteins with new chemical functionalities, biocontainment through genetic firewalls

vocabulary.definition: The set of rules by which a sequence of nucleotide triplets (codons) in mRNA is translated into a sequence of amino acids in a protein. The standard code uses 61 sense codons for 20 amino acids and 3 stop codons (UAA, UAG, UGA).

The redundancy of the genetic code, where multiple codons encode the same amino acid. For example, leucine is encoded by six different codons (UUA, UUG, CUU, CUC, CUA, CUG). This redundancy primarily occurs at the third (wobble) position.

Synthetic nucleotides that form new base pairs orthogonal to the natural A-T and G-C pairs. Developed by Steven Benner's lab, AEGIS includes pairs like Z-P and S-B, expanding the genetic alphabet from 4 to 8+ letters.

An amino acid not among the 20 canonical amino acids encoded by the standard genetic code. nsAAs can be site-specifically incorporated into proteins using engineered aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase/tRNA pairs that recognize reassigned codons.

The process of modifying synonymous codons in a gene to match the codon usage bias of a target host organism, improving translation efficiency and protein expression without changing the amino acid sequence.

The third nucleotide position in a codon, which often tolerates base substitutions without altering the encoded amino acid. This is due to non-standard base pairing between the third codon position and the first position of the anticodon.

The concept of building biological molecules or even entire organisms using mirror-image chirality: D-amino acids instead of L-amino acids, and L-sugars instead of D-sugars. Mirror biomolecules would be invisible to natural enzymes and immune systems.

An enzyme that charges (aminoacylates) a specific tRNA with its corresponding amino acid. Engineered orthogonal synthetase/tRNA pairs are used to incorporate non-standard amino acids at reassigned codons.

sections.details:
The Universal Code and Its Redundancy

The genetic code is the Rosetta Stone of molecular biology: a mapping from 64 nucleotide triplets (codons) to 20 amino acids and 3 stop signals. The code is degenerate (redundant) because there are more codons than amino acids. Most amino acids are encoded by 2-6 synonymous codons, differing primarily at the wobble position (the third base). This degeneracy is not random: it buffers against point mutations, as many third-position changes are silent.

The base pair code itself (A-T, G-C hydrogen bonding) underlies information storage in DNA. The ribosomal translation code converts mRNA codons to amino acids via tRNA adaptors. These two coding layers, base pairing for replication and codon-anticodon recognition for translation, are the foundation of all life.

Expanding the Genetic Alphabet: AEGIS

The AEGIS (Artificially Expanded Genetic Information System) project, led by Steven Benner, has created synthetic nucleotides that form orthogonal base pairs. The synthetic bases Z (6-amino-5-nitro-2(1H)-pyridinone) and P (2-amino-imidazo[1,2-a]-1,3,5-triazin-4(8H)-one) pair with each other but not with natural bases. Similarly, S and B form another synthetic pair. This expands the genetic alphabet from 4 letters to 8 (or more), potentially encoding far more information per position. AEGIS bases can be replicated by engineered polymerases and have been used in diagnostic applications (e.g., the FDA-approved COBAS assay for HIV and hepatitis).

Non-Standard Amino Acids

While AEGIS expands the nucleotide alphabet, non-standard amino acids (nsAAs) expand the protein alphabet. The strategy involves reassigning a codon (typically a stop codon freed by genome recoding, like UAG in the GRO) to an orthogonal tRNA charged with a non-standard amino acid by an engineered aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. Over 200 nsAAs have been incorporated into proteins, adding chemical functionalities not found in nature: click chemistry handles (azides, alkynes), photo-crosslinkers, fluorescent amino acids, post-translational modification mimics, and metal-chelating residues.

Codon Optimization for Expression

Codon optimization is a practical application of code degeneracy. Different organisms have different preferences for which synonymous codons they use (codon usage bias), reflecting the abundance of corresponding tRNAs. When expressing a gene from one organism in another (e.g., a human gene in E. coli), replacing rare codons with the host's preferred synonymous codons can dramatically improve protein yield. This is a key step in the Week 2 homework design challenge.

Mirror Biology: A Frontier and a Concern

Church's lecture raised mirror biology as both a scientific frontier and a biosafety concern. Natural biology uses L-amino acids and D-sugars exclusively. A mirror-image organism would use D-amino acids and L-sugars. Because natural enzymes (including those of the immune system, predators, and decomposers) are stereospecific, they would not recognize mirror biomolecules. A mirror bacterium could potentially be invisible to immune defenses and resistant to natural degradation, posing unique containment challenges that the scientific community is actively debating.

quizQuestions.question: Why is the genetic code described as 'degenerate'?
options: Because it has accumulated many errors over evolutionary time
Because multiple different codons can encode the same amino acid
Because some codons do not encode any amino acid
Because the code differs between prokaryotes and eukaryotes
quizQuestions.explanation: Degeneracy (redundancy) means that most amino acids are encoded by more than one codon. With 64 codons and only 20 amino acids (plus stops), there is necessarily overlap. For example, leucine has six codons. This degeneracy primarily occurs at the third (wobble) position and helps buffer the proteome against point mutations.

quizQuestions.question: What is the purpose of AEGIS (Artificially Expanded Genetic Information System)?
options: To create new amino acids for protein engineering
To add synthetic base pairs (like Z-P) that expand the genetic alphabet beyond the natural 4 letters
To improve the accuracy of DNA sequencing platforms
To replace the natural genetic code in all organisms
quizQuestions.explanation: AEGIS creates synthetic nucleotides that form new, orthogonal base pairs (Z-P, S-B) that do not cross-pair with natural A-T and G-C. This expands the genetic alphabet, increasing information density and enabling new applications in diagnostics, data storage, and synthetic biology.

quizQuestions.question: Why does mirror biology raise biosafety concerns?
options: Mirror organisms would be too fragile to survive outside the lab
Mirror DNA cannot be sequenced with current technology
Natural immune systems and degradative enzymes cannot recognize mirror-image biomolecules
Mirror proteins are toxic to all known organisms
quizQuestions.explanation: Natural enzymes, including immune receptors, proteases, and nucleases, are stereospecific: they recognize the specific chirality (handedness) of natural L-amino acids and D-sugars. Mirror-image biomolecules (D-amino acids, L-sugars) would be invisible to these systems, meaning a mirror organism could evade immune defenses and resist natural degradation.

sections.title: Gel Electrophoresis & Restriction Enzymes
keyPoints: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size: smaller fragments migrate faster through the agarose matrix toward the positive electrode
DNA is negatively charged (due to phosphate backbone) and migrates toward the anode (positive electrode) when an electric field is applied
Restriction enzymes are bacterial endonucleases that cut DNA at specific recognition sequences (typically 4-8 bp palindromic sites)
Type II restriction enzymes (e.g., EcoRI, HindIII, BamHI) are the most commonly used in molecular biology: they cut at defined positions within or near their recognition sequence
Some restriction enzymes produce sticky ends (5' or 3' overhangs, e.g., EcoRI: 5'-G^AATTC-3'), while others produce blunt ends (e.g., EcoRV: 5'-GAT^ATC-3')
DNA ladders (molecular weight markers) run alongside samples to calibrate fragment sizes by comparison
Agarose concentration determines the separation range: higher concentrations resolve smaller fragments; lower concentrations resolve larger fragments
DNA is visualized with intercalating dyes (ethidium bromide or safer alternatives like SYBR Safe) that fluoresce under UV or blue light

vocabulary.definition: A technique for separating DNA (or RNA) fragments by size. An agarose gel matrix acts as a molecular sieve; when an electric field is applied, negatively charged nucleic acids migrate toward the positive electrode, with smaller fragments moving faster.

A bacterial enzyme that recognizes a specific DNA sequence (restriction site) and cleaves the phosphodiester backbone at defined positions. Part of bacterial defense against foreign DNA (e.g., bacteriophage).

A DNA sequence that reads the same on both strands in the 5' to 3' direction. Most Type II restriction enzyme recognition sites are palindromic. For example, EcoRI recognizes 5'-GAATTC-3', which reads the same on the complementary strand.
Short single-stranded overhangs (either 5' or 3') produced when a restriction enzyme cuts the two DNA strands at staggered positions. Compatible sticky ends can base-pair and be ligated together.
DNA ends with no single-stranded overhang, produced when a restriction enzyme cuts both strands at the same position within the recognition site (e.g., EcoRV cuts GAT|ATC to produce blunt ends).
A mixture of DNA fragments of known sizes used as a molecular weight standard in gel electrophoresis. Run in a lane alongside experimental samples to calibrate the size of unknown fragments.
A fluorescent intercalating dye that inserts between DNA base pairs and fluoresces under UV light, used to visualize DNA in gels. It is a mutagen; safer alternatives include SYBR Safe and GelRed.

A widely used Type II restriction enzyme from E. coli that recognizes the palindromic sequence 5'-GAATTC-3' and cuts between G and A on both strands, producing 4-nt 5' sticky ends (5'-AATT overhangs).

sections.details:
Gel Electrophoresis: Separating DNA by Size

Agarose gel electrophoresis is one of the most fundamental techniques in molecular biology, and it forms the basis of the Week 2 Gel Art Lab. The principle is simple: DNA molecules carry a uniform negative charge along their phosphate backbone, so they migrate toward the positive electrode (anode) when placed in an electric field. The agarose gel acts as a molecular sieve: smaller DNA fragments navigate through the pores more easily and migrate faster, while larger fragments are retarded.

The agarose concentration determines the effective separation range. A 0.8% gel resolves fragments from ~1-12 kb well, while a 2% gel is better for separating small fragments (100-1000 bp). The gel is typically cast in a horizontal slab, submerged in running buffer (TAE or TBE), and run at a constant voltage for 30-60 minutes.

Visualizing DNA

DNA is invisible in a plain gel. To visualize it, intercalating dyes such as ethidium bromide (EtBr) are added either to the gel or as a post-stain. EtBr inserts between base pairs and fluoresces bright orange under UV light. Because EtBr is a potential mutagen, many labs now use safer alternatives like SYBR Safe or GelRed. A DNA ladder (a set of fragments of known sizes) is always run alongside experimental samples to calibrate fragment sizes.

Restriction Enzymes: Molecular Scissors

Restriction enzymes (restriction endonucleases) are bacterial enzymes that evolved as a defense mechanism against bacteriophage DNA. They recognize specific DNA sequences, usually 4-8 bp palindromes, and cleave the phosphodiester backbone at defined positions. Bacteria protect their own DNA from cleavage by methylating the recognition sites.

The Week 2 lab uses several common restriction enzymes:

EcoRI (5'-G^AATTC-3'): Cuts to produce 4-nucleotide 5' sticky ends. One of the first restriction enzymes discovered and among the most widely used.

HindIII (5'-A^AGCTT-3'): Produces 4-nt 5' sticky ends. From Haemophilus influenzae.

BamHI (5'-G^GATCC-3'): Produces 4-nt 5' sticky ends compatible with BglII and BclI overhangs.

KpnI (5'-GGTAC^C-3'): Produces 4-nt 3' sticky ends (an unusual overhang orientation).

EcoRV (5'-GAT^ATC-3'): Produces blunt ends (no overhang), cutting both strands at the center of the palindrome.

SacI (5'-GAGCT^C-3'): Produces 4-nt 3' sticky ends.

SalI (5'-G^TCGAC-3'): Produces 4-nt 5' sticky ends.

Sticky vs. Blunt Ends

The type of end produced has practical consequences for cloning. Sticky ends (cohesive ends) have short single-stranded overhangs that can base-pair with complementary sticky ends, making ligation much more efficient. Blunt ends lack overhangs and can ligate to any other blunt end, offering flexibility but at lower efficiency. In the Gel Art Lab, students use different restriction enzymes to create characteristic banding patterns from plasmid DNA.

quizQuestions.question: Why does DNA migrate toward the positive electrode during gel electrophoresis?
options: DNA has a net positive charge due to its amino groups
The agarose gel attracts DNA molecules chemically
DNA has a net negative charge due to its phosphate backbone
The electric field causes DNA to denature and move randomly
quizQuestions.explanation: Each nucleotide in DNA contributes a negatively charged phosphate group to the backbone. This gives DNA a uniform negative charge proportional to its length. In an electric field, negatively charged DNA migrates toward the positive electrode (anode).

quizQuestions.question: What is the difference between the products of EcoRI and EcoRV digestion?
options: EcoRI produces blunt ends; EcoRV produces sticky ends
EcoRI produces 5' sticky ends (4-nt overhang); EcoRV produces blunt ends
Both produce identical 4-nt 5' overhangs
EcoRI cuts single-stranded DNA; EcoRV cuts double-stranded DNA
quizQuestions.explanation: EcoRI cuts 5'-G^AATTC-3' at staggered positions, producing 4-nucleotide 5' overhangs (sticky ends). EcoRV cuts 5'-GAT^ATC-3' at the center of the palindrome, producing blunt ends with no overhang.

quizQuestions.question: Why are restriction enzyme recognition sites typically palindromic?
options: Palindromic sequences are easier for enzymes to synthesize
The enzyme binds as a homodimer (two identical subunits), each recognizing the same sequence on opposite strands
Palindromic sequences occur more frequently in bacterial genomes
Non-palindromic sequences cannot be cut by any enzyme
quizQuestions.explanation: Most Type II restriction enzymes function as homodimers: two identical protein subunits, each recognizing the same sequence on one strand. A palindromic recognition site ensures that both subunits see the same sequence on their respective strands, enabling symmetric binding and coordinated cleavage.

quizQuestions.question: How does increasing agarose concentration affect gel electrophoresis?
options: Higher concentration resolves larger fragments better
Higher concentration makes DNA migrate faster
Higher concentration creates smaller pores, better resolving smaller DNA fragments
Agarose concentration has no effect on resolution
quizQuestions.explanation: Higher agarose concentrations produce gels with smaller pores, which better separate smaller DNA fragments (100-1000 bp). Conversely, lower concentrations (larger pores) are better for resolving larger fragments (5-20 kb). Choosing the right concentration is essential for the size range of interest.

sections.title: Central Dogma & Expression
keyPoints: The central dogma: DNA is transcribed to mRNA by RNA polymerase, and mRNA is translated to protein by ribosomes
An expression cassette contains the minimum elements needed for gene expression: promoter, ribosome binding site (RBS), coding sequence (CDS), and terminator
Codons are read in a fixed reading frame set by the start codon (AUG); frameshift mutations are usually catastrophic
Codon optimization matches the synonymous codon usage of the expression host to improve translation efficiency
Reverse translation converts an amino acid sequence back to a DNA coding sequence, with choices at degenerate positions guided by codon usage tables
Metabolic engineering redirects cellular metabolism by introducing or modifying enzyme-coding genes to produce desired small molecules, fuels, or therapeutics
The bioFPGA concept (Jacobson) envisions cells as reconfigurable biological circuits, analogous to field-programmable gate arrays in electronics
Synthetic biology standardizes biological parts (promoters, RBSs, CDSs, terminators) as modular, composable genetic elements

vocabulary.definition: The fundamental principle of molecular biology stating that genetic information flows from DNA to RNA (transcription) to protein (translation). While exceptions exist (reverse transcription, RNA replication), this describes the primary information flow in cells.

A minimal genetic unit designed for gene expression, containing a promoter (drives transcription), a ribosome binding site (RBS, positions the ribosome for translation), the coding sequence (CDS), and a terminator (stops transcription).
A DNA sequence upstream of a gene that recruits RNA polymerase to initiate transcription. Promoter strength determines the rate of mRNA production. Common lab promoters include T7, lac, and CMV.
A sequence in mRNA (Shine-Dalgarno sequence in prokaryotes, Kozak sequence in eukaryotes) that positions the ribosome for translation initiation at the correct start codon (AUG).

The grouping of nucleotides into consecutive, non-overlapping triplets (codons) starting from a fixed point. There are three possible reading frames on each strand; the correct one is set by the start codon. A frameshift mutation shifts all downstream codons.

The computational process of converting an amino acid sequence back into a DNA (or mRNA) coding sequence. Because the genetic code is degenerate, there are many possible DNA sequences for any given protein, and codon optimization selects the best one for the target host.

The practice of optimizing cellular metabolic pathways by introducing, deleting, or modifying enzyme-coding genes. Goals include producing valuable chemicals (drugs, biofuels, materials) or improving cellular fitness for industrial applications.

A concept proposed by Joseph Jacobson where cells function as biological field-programmable gate arrays: reconfigurable living circuits that can be reprogrammed by changing their genetic instructions, analogous to how electronic FPGAs are reconfigured via software.

sections.details:
The Central Dogma: Information Flow in Biology

The central dogma of molecular biology, articulated by Francis Crick in 1958, describes the flow of genetic information: DNA → RNA → Protein. DNA serves as the stable, heritable information store. Transcription by RNA polymerase copies a gene's DNA sequence into messenger RNA (mRNA). Translation by ribosomes then decodes the mRNA into a polypeptide chain, reading three nucleotides (one codon) at a time and adding the corresponding amino acid via charged tRNA adaptors.

Understanding this flow is essential for the Week 2 homework design challenge, where students reverse-translate a protein of interest back to a DNA coding sequence and build a complete expression cassette.

Building an Expression Cassette

To express a gene in a host organism, you need more than just the coding sequence. A functional expression cassette includes four key elements:

1. Promoter: A DNA sequence upstream of the gene that recruits RNA polymerase. The choice of promoter determines expression level and regulation. Strong constitutive promoters (like T7 in E. coli or CMV in mammalian cells) drive high expression; inducible promoters (like lac or tet) allow controlled expression.

2. Ribosome Binding Site (RBS): In prokaryotes, the Shine-Dalgarno sequence (5'-AGGAGG-3') base-pairs with the 16S rRNA of the small ribosomal subunit, positioning the ribosome to initiate translation at the AUG start codon. In eukaryotes, the Kozak consensus sequence serves a similar function. RBS strength is a major determinant of protein yield.

3. Coding Sequence (CDS): The open reading frame encoding the protein, beginning with ATG (start codon, encoding methionine) and ending with a stop codon (TAA, TAG, or TGA). For heterologous expression, the CDS is typically codon-optimized for the host.

4. Terminator: A sequence downstream of the CDS that signals RNA polymerase to stop transcription and release the mRNA. In prokaryotes, rho-independent terminators form a hairpin loop followed by a poly-U tract.

Reverse Translation and Codon Optimization

When you know the protein you want to produce but need to design the DNA, you perform reverse translation: converting the amino acid sequence back to codons. Because the genetic code is degenerate (most amino acids have 2-6 codons), there are astronomically many possible DNA sequences for any protein. Codon optimization selects synonymous codons that match the codon usage bias of the intended host organism. For example, E. coli strongly prefers certain leucine codons (e.g., CUG) over others (e.g., CUA). Using the host's preferred codons ensures abundant tRNAs are available, improving translation speed and protein yield.

Metabolic Engineering and the bioFPGA

Metabolic engineering applies the read-write-edit toolkit to redirect cellular metabolism. By introducing heterologous enzyme genes (written and codon-optimized for the host), knocking out competing pathways (via CRISPR editing), and fine-tuning expression levels (via promoter and RBS engineering), researchers can turn microbes into factories producing pharmaceuticals (artemisinin, insulin), biofuels (ethanol, butanol), materials (spider silk, bioplastics), and flavors/fragrances.

Jacobson's bioFPGA concept takes this further: just as electronic FPGAs can be reconfigured for different computational tasks via software, cells could be reprogrammed by swapping genetic circuits. Standardized biological parts (BioBrick-style promoters, RBSs, CDSs, and terminators) would serve as the configurable elements, and large-scale DNA synthesis would provide the programming capability. This vision motivates much of the synthetic biology field's emphasis on modularity and standardization.

quizQuestions.question: What are the four essential components of an expression cassette?
options: Origin of replication, antibiotic resistance gene, multiple cloning site, reporter gene
Promoter, ribosome binding site (RBS), coding sequence (CDS), terminator
Enhancer, silencer, intron, poly-A signal
Leader sequence, signal peptide, transmembrane domain, GPI anchor
quizQuestions.explanation: A minimal expression cassette requires: (1) a promoter to recruit RNA polymerase, (2) a ribosome binding site to position the ribosome, (3) the coding sequence for the protein, and (4) a terminator to stop transcription. These four elements are sufficient for gene expression in a host cell.

quizQuestions.question: Why is codon optimization important when expressing a human gene in E. coli?
options: E. coli cannot read human codons at all
Human codons use a different genetic code than E. coli
E. coli has different tRNA abundances, so matching its preferred codons improves translation efficiency
Codon optimization changes the protein sequence to be more compatible with E. coli
quizQuestions.explanation: While E. coli and humans use the same genetic code, they have different codon usage biases reflecting different tRNA abundances. Rare codons in E. coli can cause ribosome stalling and reduce protein yield. Codon optimization replaces rare codons with synonymous preferred codons without changing the amino acid sequence.

quizQuestions.question: What is the bioFPGA concept?
options: A biological computer chip made of DNA transistors
A method for synthesizing field-programmable gate arrays using biological materials
The idea that cells can serve as reconfigurable biological circuits, reprogrammable by changing their genetic instructions
A technique for 3D printing biological circuits onto silicon wafers
quizQuestions.explanation: Jacobson's bioFPGA concept draws an analogy between electronic FPGAs (which can be reconfigured for different tasks via software) and cells (which can be reprogrammed by changing their DNA). Standardized genetic parts serve as configurable elements, and DNA synthesis provides the programming capability.

quizQuestions.question: What is reverse translation in the context of gene design?
options: Translating mRNA back into DNA using reverse transcriptase
Converting an amino acid sequence back to a DNA coding sequence computationally, choosing codons optimized for the host
Reading a protein sequence backward from C-terminus to N-terminus
Using ribosomes to synthesize DNA from protein templates
quizQuestions.explanation: Reverse translation is the computational process of converting a known amino acid sequence into a DNA coding sequence. Because the genetic code is degenerate, there are many possible DNA sequences for any protein. The process involves selecting the best synonymous codons for the intended expression host (codon optimization).

parts.title: Part 0: Gel Electrophoresis Basics
parts.description: Learn the fundamental principles of gel electrophoresis, including how DNA migrates in agarose gels, the role of molecular weight markers (DNA ladders), and how to estimate fragment sizes from gel images. Review the theory before the hands-on lab.

parts.title: Part 1: Virtual Restriction Digest (Benchling)
parts.description: Use the Benchling platform to perform a virtual restriction digest of a plasmid DNA sequence. Identify restriction enzyme recognition sites, predict the resulting fragment sizes, and simulate the gel banding pattern. Compare single and double digests.

parts.title: Part 2: Gel Art Lab
parts.description: Hands-on lab: digest plasmid DNA with various restriction enzymes (EcoRI, HindIII, BamHI, KpnI, EcoRV, SacI, SalI), run the products on agarose gels, and create artistic banding patterns ('gel art'). Document the gel images and identify fragment sizes using the DNA ladder.

parts.title: Part 3: DNA Design Challenge
parts.description: Design a complete gene expression construct: (1) Choose a protein of interest and find its amino acid sequence, (2) Reverse-translate the sequence to DNA, choosing codons optimized for your expression host, (3) Build a full expression cassette with promoter, RBS, coding sequence, and terminator, (4) Verify the design computationally.

parts.title: Part 4: Twist Order
parts.description: Submit your designed DNA sequence for synthesis by Twist Bioscience. Learn the practical steps of ordering synthetic DNA: sequence formatting, checking for synthesis constraints (repeats, GC content, secondary structures), and understanding turnaround times and costs.

parts.title: Part 5: DNA Read/Write/Edit Essay Questions
parts.description: Answer essay questions covering the week's lecture content on DNA sequencing technologies, synthesis methods, and gene editing approaches. Demonstrate understanding of the connections between reading, writing, and editing DNA and their applications in synthetic biology.
